7.8.19  5:40 am   as I try to type this up it seems stupider because I can't quite figure out how to word it properly to make the distinction I'm worried about clear.

But do you think chords have functions, or is it just notes that are functional?

      And chords that have a lot of notes with a certain function end up functioning like that because on average the set of notes ends up functioning like the function that is most common amongst the notes?

     Like, is V7 dominant because V7 is dominant? Or is V7 dominant because 7, 2, and 4 are dominant-function-sounding notes in the scale and they make up the majority of the V7 chord?
original_html:

or maybe i should consult an actual psychiatrist
or maybe i should just stay in bed forever

html: 7.7.19  6:28 am   i've recently taken this approach to songwriting that's based around recording little song ideas whenever i get them and just having a constant pile of 15-second-long demos to take from and expand upon whenever i want to. this has been working fine so far, but i fear that the number of ideas will soon be so large that i won't be able to make all of them into full songs at a reasonable pace while also developing them to their maximum potential. do i stop recording ideas so fast, giving me more time to work on what's already there but also potentially missing out on what could be some great ideas? do i make them into full songs faster, letting me catch up to the rate at which i'm recording demos but also not giving me enough time to make each song the best version of itself? is there a compromise? do a take a different songwriting approach? help!
